newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Poor repair business hurts Singapore marine firms.
newsitem.headline: Poor repair business hurts Singapore marine firms.

text.p: Continued weakness in the ship repair business is expected to hurt the 1996 earnings of Singapore's marine-based companies, analysts said on Wednesday.
The two major players, Keppel Corp and Sembawang Corp, are due to announce in early March their full year results for the 1996 financial year ended December 31.
"We should see lower than expected profits from ship repair," Liew Yin Sze, chief economist at J.M. Sassoon said, referring to Keppel and Sembawang.
Analysts said the ship repair businesss faced increased competition from low-cost yards in China and the Middle East.
Singapore also had surplus dock capacity, they said.
The situation had not improved in 1996 and a turnaround was not expected in the near future, they added.
"It was not a positive year for the ship repair segment. We see it more as a structural than a cyclical problem," Liew said.
The latest Estimate Directory showed a consensus forecast for Keppel's net 1996 profit at Singapore $221.9 million (US$157.38 million), up 3.65 percent from S$214.09 million in the previous year.
